choices.text: Comedone is a Primary Skin Lesion
Comedone is a Specific Lesion of Acne Vulgaris
Closed Comedones are also called as Black Heads
Comedones are earliest Lesions of Rosacea

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding comedones?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Comedone is a specific Lesion of Acne Vulgaris

 

Explanation:

 

  • Comedones (are considered as special lesions, NOT primary skin lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris
  • Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne, but NOT Rosacea.
  • They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.
  • When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed Comedone or whitehead (NOT black head as mentioned in option C)

 

 

  • When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (black head).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Comedones are specific skin lesions of Acne vulgaris, with closed comedones known as whiteheads and open comedones as blackheads, and are not related to the initial presentation of Rosacea.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.1

questions.text: A 19-Year-Old Girl came to Dermatology OPD with complaints of Facial Lesions. On examination, Multiple Comedones, Papules, Pustules & Nodulocystic Lesions were present. Most likely Diagnosis for these examination findings in this patient would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acne Vulgaris

 

Option B.

 

  • The age of the patient & the presence of comedones, papules , pustules & nodulocystic lesions on the face are suggestive of acne vulgaris.

 

 

  • It is commonly seen in Teenagers & Young Adults.
  • The condition can vary from very mild comedonal acne to severe aggressive pustular acne. These eventually may lead to scarring due to sinus formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acne Rosacea or Rosacea:

 

  • It is predominantly a disease with onset in middle aged adults (30-50 years old) & involves the convexities of the face.
  • Comedones are absent in Rosacea

 

Option C. Lichen Planus:

 

  • The lesions of lichen planus can be described as 5Ps – Purple Polygonal, Pruritic, Plane Topped (Flat), Papules. NOT as described in this question.

 

Option D. Scabies:

 

  • Adult Scabies does not have Facial lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acne vulgaris is diagnosed by the presence of comedones, inflammatory papules, pustules, and occasionally nodules, primarily on the face, chest, and back, and is a common dermatological condition among teenagers and young adults.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.21 & 90.22

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of SAHA syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synovitis

 

Explanation:

 

SAHA syndrome is NOT associated with Synovitis.

 

  • Seborrhoea
  • Acne
  • Hirsutism
  • Androgenetic alopecia

 

SAPHO Syndrome consists of:

 

  • Synovitis
  • Acne
  • Pustulosis
  • Hyperostosis
  • Osteitis

 

Important Syndromes Associated with Acne:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SAHA syndrome is a disorder characterized by Seborrhoea, Acne, Hirsutism, and Androgenetic alopecia, which are associated with increased androgen activity and do not include Synovitis, an unrelated inflammatory joint condition.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.8 & 90.9

choices.text: Hypercornification of Duct

questions.text: All of the following have an aetiological role in the causation of Acne Vulgaris EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oily Food

 

Option D.

 

  • Excessive sebum production leading to Oily skin is one of the causative factors of acne, but oily food is not directly implicated.

 

Various combinations of Aetiological factors for Acne are

 

  • Oily skin due to Increased Sebaceous Gland activity under the influence of androgens.
  • Abnormal follicular differentiation with increased keratinisation- Hyper Cornification if duct due to Increased IL-1
  • Microbial hyper colonisation of the follicular canal with Cutibacterium Acnes leading to its inflammation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Androgens

 

  • Androgens are known to play a role in the development of acne by increasing sebum production, which is a key factor in acne pathogenesis

 

Option B. Bacterial proliferation

 

  • Bacterial proliferation, particularly Propionibacterium acnes, within the sebaceous follicles is a contributing factor to the development of inflammatory acne lesions

 

Option C. Hypercornification of the duct

 

  • Hypercornification of the duct, which refers to the overproduction of keratin leading to plugging of the follicle, is a primary event in acne formation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While androgens, bacterial proliferation, and hyper cornification of the pilosebaceous duct are established etiological factors in acne vulgaris, the role of oily food remains uncertain and is not considered a direct causative factor according to current evidence.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.18 & 90.22

questions.text: A teenager with oily skin presents with Nodulocystic Acne as shown in the given image below. What is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral Isotretinoin

 

Option A.

 

  • According to the Global alliance algorithm for acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Oral Steroids:

 

  • They can be used as a short-term adjunct in severe inflammatory acne but are not the primary treatment modality.

 

Option C. Topical Retinoids:

 

  • They are used for mild to moderate acne and as maintenance therapy but are often not potent enough alone for severe nodulocystic acne.

 

Option D. Topical Clindamycin

 

  • Topical Clindamycin is an antibiotic that can help reduce the bacterial load but is also not sufficient as monotherapy for severe nodulocystic acne.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral isotretinoin is the treatment of choice for severe nodulocystic acne due to its comprehensive action on various pathogenic factors of the condition, and it is often commenced early to prevent scarring.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.7 & 90.37

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with pustular acne comes to your clinic for follow up saying that her acne has not reduced even after taking medications for 6 months. Which of the following drugs will you now prescribe?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isotretinoin

 

Option C.

 

Oral Isotretinoin

 

  • It is an oral retinoid is indicated for the treatment of severe acne (nodular, acne conglobata) & recalcitrant acne
  • Recalcitrant acne is poorly responsive acne, less than 50% improvement after 6 months of therapy with combined oral & topical antibiotics

 

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

 

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for improving outcomes in Acne

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oral Erythromycin

 

  • It is typically used for its antibacterial properties in acne treatment but may not be effective in severe, treatment-resistant cases.

 

Option B. Oral Steroids

 

  • They can be used for their anti-inflammatory properties but are not a primary treatment for severe acne.

 

Option D. Oral Tetracyclines

 

  • Oral tetracyclines, like erythromycin, are used for their antibacterial effect but may not be sufficient in cases unresponsive to long-term treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of severe acne that does not respond to conventional therapies, isotretinoin is the most effective option and is known to significantly improve or even resolve the condition.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.7 & 90.37

questions.text:
Consider the Following Statements:

 

  1. Trifarotene has been approved for Acne.
  2. Clascoterone Propionate Cream is effective in Acne.

 

Which of the above statements is/are TRUE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clascoterone Propionate 1% cream inhibits Androgen Receptors & is Effective in Acne.
  • Trifarotene is a Topical Fourth Generation Retinoid which was approved recently for Acne.

 

Ref:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9166940/#:~:text=Trifarotene%2C%20a%20first%2Din%2D,both%20facial%20and%20truncal%20acnes.

https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamadermatology/fullarticle/2765025

Sanchez C, Keri J. Androgen Receptor Inhibitors in the Treatment of Acne Vulgaris: Efficacy and Safety Profiles of Clascoterone 1% Cream. Clin CosmetInvestig Dermatol. 2022 Jul 15; 15:1357-1366. Doi: 10.2147/CCID.S289750. PMID: 35874458; PMCID: PMC9297041.

choices.text: Oral Acitretin
Oral Contraceptive Pills

questions.text: A teenage girl with moderate acne also has irregular menses. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oral Contraceptive Pills

 

Option D.

 

  • OCPs are the most effective treatment for moderate acne with irregular menses.
  • OCP administration will boost sex hormone binding globulin SHBG and, as a result, lower free androgens, which are crucial in the development of acne.
  • OCPs also assist in regulating the menstrual cycle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oral Acitretin

 

  • It is a systemic retinoid used for psoriasis, not typically indicated for acne or menstrual irregularities.

 

Option B. Oral Isotretinoin

 

  • It is a potent treatment for severe recalcitrant nodular acne, not typically the first choice for moderate acne, and it requires strict contraception due to its teratogenicity.

 

Option C. Oral Minocycline

 

  • It is an antibiotic used for acne; however, it would not address the hormonal component of the patient's irregular menses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral contraceptive pills are a suitable treatment for a female with moderate acne and irregular menses due to their dual effect on regulating the menstrual cycle and reducing the hormonal contribution to acne.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.43

Fitzpatrick’s Textbook, 8th Edition Page 909

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who has had Erythematous Papulo Pustular Lesions over the Centre of her Face for the past two years comes to the Dermatology OPD. Comedones are absent. Background Erythema and Telangiectasia are present. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rosacea

 

Option B.

 

  • The patient presents with erythema and papules on the central face, which are symptoms of acne rosacea.
  • Alcohol, spicy food, sunlight exposure, and emotional disturbances can all cause it.
  • Later on, telangiectasia also appears in patients.
  • Additionally, they frequently experience rapid flushing in response to temperature changes.
  • Rosacea is more common in women between the ages of 30 and 50.
  • In rosacea, the innate immune response seems to be altered. There is increased protease activity as well as increased toll-like receptor 2 TLR-2 activity.
  • Proliferation of Demodex mites in the pilosebaceous follicles of the face has also been proposed as a potential aetiological factor in cutaneous & ocular inflammation.
  • Meibomian gland dysfunction appears to be closely linked to the pathogenesis of ocular rosacea.

 

The table below shows the subtypes & the corresponding treatment options. The subtypes are not equivalent to the progression of the disease.

 

 

 

The image below shows Rosacea:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acne

 

  • It is usually accompanied by comedones, which are not present in this patient.

 

Option C. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

 

  • It may cause a malar rash but is typically accompanied by systemic symptoms and other cutaneous signs, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Melasma

 

  • This presents as symmetrical hyperpigmented patches on the face, without papulopustular lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rosacea should be considered in adults presenting with Central Facial Erythema, Papulopustular Lesions, and Telangiectasia, particularly in the Absence of Comedones.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 91.1-6

questions.text: Flare of acne can be associated with all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

Option C.

 

  • Penicillin is not associated with Acne Flare.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phenytoin:

 

  • Phenytoin is known to induce acneiform eruptions as a side effect due to its influence on the metabolism of steroids within the body and its effect on the epidermal growth factor. Therefore, phenytoin can be associated with acne flares.

 

Option B. Whey Protein:

 

  • There is evidence that whey protein, which is a milk derivative, can exacerbate acne due to its ability to stimulate insulin and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1), which in turn can increase sebum production and proliferation of skin cells, leading to acne.

 

Option D. Anabolic Steroids:

 

  • Anabolic steroids are well-documented in causing acne due to their androgenic effects, which increase sebum production and can lead to the development of acneiform eruptions, particularly on the trunk.

 

Drug induced acne (Acneiform eruptions) are associated with the following:

 

  • Topical or Systemic Steroids (most common)
  • Anabolic steroids: Danazol Stanazolol
  • Anticonvulsants: Carbamazepine, Phenytoin, Phenobarbitone
  • Antituberculosis: Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide
  • Whey protein also can be associated with Acne Flares.
  • Clinically, Acneiform Eruptions are characteristically Monomorphic
  • Drugs most commonly implicated in Acneiform Eruptions:
  • World wide-Steroids
  • India- Isoniazid

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In considering drug-induced acne, healthcare providers should be aware that medications like phenytoin, whey protein supplements, and anabolic steroids can induce acne flares, whereas penicillin is not commonly associated with acne.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.10, 90.21 & 90.22

questions.text: Identify the following condition?
questions.solution:
Ans.C) Rhinophyma

 

Option C.

 

  • A condition known as rhinophyma, or "potato nose," is characterised by hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the sebaceous glands in the tip of the nose.
  • It frequently occurs in people with Phymatous rosacea, a type of chronic rosacea.
  • It can affect the nose (rhinophyma), chin (gnatophyma), forehead (metophyma), ears (otophyma) and eyelids (blepharophyma). 
  • It is not a cancer.
  • Rhinophyma appears over the nose as a pink, lobulated mass with superficial vascular dilation.
  • Men past middle age are the main victims. Patients seek advice because their enlarged nose appears distorted or because it is obstructing their breathing or vision.
  • A skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis of rhinophyma, though it can also be made clinically.
  • Sebaceous Gland Hypertrophy, Hyperplasia, and Fibrosis are visible on rhinophyma histology.
  • The most frequent reason for treatment is Aesthetic. Surgical Removal of Extra Tissue with Nose Remodelling or CO2 laser ablation are two options.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rosacea

 

  • It is a chronic skin condition that can lead to rhinophyma but is characterized by flushing, redness, not the bulbous nose seen in rhinophyma.

 

Option B. Acne

 

  • It is characterized by comedones, papules, pustules, and sometimes cysts, primarily affecting the face, back, and chest.
  • It does not cause the bulbous changes of the nose seen in rhinophyma.

 

Option D. Neoplasm

 

  • This refers to a new and abnormal growth of tissue, which can be benign or malignant.
  • While neoplasms can affect the nose, the picture shown is typical of rhinophyma, not a neoplasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rhinophyma is identified by a bulbous, red, and bumpy appearance of the nose due to sebaceous gland hyperplasia and connective tissue proliferation.
  • It is important to differentiate it from other conditions such as rosacea, acne, and neoplasms.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 91 Page No 91.7 & 91.14

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology in General Medicine Pg No- 1422

questions.text: Fordyce’s Spots mainly involve which of the following Sites?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lips

 

Explanation:

 

Fordyce spots / Ectopic or free-lying sebaceous glands:

 

  • They occur most commonly on the upper lip> buccal mucosa.
  • The heterotrophic sebaceous glands that make up Fordyce spots are connected directly to the skin or mucosal surface beneath them, in contrast to other sebaceous glands that open into follicles.
  • They frequently appear on the areola of the breast, skin over the penile shaft, and the vermillion border of the upper lip (m/c) buccal mucosa.
  • They frequently appear as multiple, symmetrical, discrete yellow papules.
  • Tyson glands are Fordyce spots on the penis.
  • They have no symptoms.
  • Treatment: Reassurance

 

Image: Fordyce spots on the vermillion border of both lips in A upper lip in B & buccal mucosa in C

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fordyce spots are ectopic sebaceous glands that are commonly found on the lips and oral mucosa, presenting as small, pale, painless bumps.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1392

choices.text: Ectopic Sebaceous Glands
Antibiotics are First Line Treatment
Occur commonly on Upper Lip

questions.text: Identify the CORRECT statement regarding the given condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Asymptomatic

 

Explanation:

 

Pearly penile papules

 

  • The image shows pearly penile papules. These are only present in males.
  • The coronal margin of the glans penis is where they most frequently appear as smooth, flesh-coloured papules.
  • They are benign and asymptomatic, and patient reassurance is part of the treatment.

 

Note: Fordyce Spots (Tyson's glands) are frequently mistaken for pearly penile papules.

 

  • Fordyce Spots, which are Ectopic Sebaceous Glands, are frequently seen on the penis shaft.
  • Fordyce spots on the penile shaft are shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pearly penile papules are asymptomatic, benign, flesh-colored papules that typically appear around the corona of the glans penis and do not require treatment.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.24 111.5

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology, 9th Edition. Pg No:58

choices.text: None of the above

questions.text: You as an intern, are accompanying your Dermatology Senior Resident for reference of a 2-Week-Old Neonate in Paediatric Ward with the following skin finding. You diagnose it as a Disorder of Eccrine Glands, which the Senior Resident in Derma also accepts. At what level does the Obstruction occur in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stratum Corneum

 

Option A.

 

  • The image displays clear, thin-walled, superficial vesicles that resemble water drops on a newborn with a diameter of 1-2 mm and no accompanying erythema.
  • It is indicative of miliaria, an eccrine sweat gland disorder.
  • Because the sweat ducts' ability to maintain patency takes longer to develop in infants, miliaria Crystallina frequently affects them.
  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, Thin-walled vesicles with a Diameter of 1-2 mm and no inflammatory areola, which typically do not cause symptoms and grow on the trunk of crops.
  • Recurring crops may happen in febrile illnesses that are persistent. The vesicles quickly burst, and superficial, branny desquamation follows.

 

Miliaria, also known as sweat rash, occurs when the eccrine sweat ducts get blocked. The level of obstruction determines the type of miliaria:

 

 

  • Miliaria crystallina stratum corneum
  • Miliaria rubra- Malpighian layer
  • Miliaria profunda- Dermoepidermal junction

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The Malpighian Layer (also known as the Stratum Malpighii):

 

  • It is not a site of sweat duct obstruction in miliaria crystallina.

 

Option C: The Dermoepidermal Junction

 

  • It is typically involved in miliaria profunda, a deeper form of miliaria, not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Miliaria crystallina is a disorder of the eccrine glands where the obstruction typically occurs at the level of the stratum corneum, causing the sweat to be trapped beneath the skin and leading to the appearance of tiny clear blisters or bumps on the skin.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 94 Page No 94.12

choices.text: Hidradenitis Suppurativa is the likely Diagnosis
Smoking & Obesity are the two main factors associated with it
TNF Alpha Inhibitors like Adalimumab can be used in treatment
Fox Fordyce Disease is the other name for this condition

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese female patient, complaining of repeated attacks of painful swellings & discharge over bilateral axilla since 6 years as shown in the image below. Which of the following is WRONG statement related to this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fox Fordyce Disease is the other name for this condition

 

Option D:

 

  • Fox Fordyce disease or apocrine miliaria- obliteration of the apocrine duct at the infundibulum.
  • The given image shows hidradenitis suppurativa or inverse acne (NOT Fox Fordyce Disease i.e. Option D).

 

Explanation:

 

Hidradenitis Suppurativa:

 

  • It is a disease of occlusion of Hair Follicles & Apocrine Ducts.
    • There are painful, deep seated inflamed lesions in the apocrine gland bearing areas of the body, most commonly the axillary inguinal & anogenital regions.
    • More common in young women of ages 20-29 years. Obesity & smoking (Option B) are the two main factors associated with hidradenitis suppurativa.

 

Treatment includes:

 

  • Antibiotics – tetracycline, clindamycin
  • Intralesional corticosteroids
  • Immunosuppressants
  • Acitretin
  • Anti TNF alpha therapy (Adalimumab i.e. Option C)
  • Surgery

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients presenting with chronic painful swellings and discharge in areas rich in apocrine glands, consider hidradenitis suppurativa as a likely diagnosis.
  • Smokingcessation and weight management are key components of managing this condition, and TNF alpha inhibitors may be used in treatment.
  • Fox-Fordyce disease is a separate condition and should not be confused with Hidradenitis suppurativa.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 92 Page No 92.1-10

Online Resource https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534867/

choices.text: Axilla
Face
Palms & Soles
Scalp

questions.text: Apocrine Glands are present in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axilla

 

Option A.

 

Apocrine glands:

 

  • They are indeed present in the axilla, or underarm region.
  • Apocrine gland is present in the subcutaneous fat deep into the dermis
  • They produce odourless secretions
  • Bacterial decomposition converts the odourless secretions into secretions with odour
  • Apocrine glands secrete oily sweat filled with lipids and proteins
  • Apocrine sweat glands open along with hair follicles
  • They are under adrenergic control
  • They are a type of exocrine gland found in several areas of the body, primarily in regions abundant in hair follicles such as the axillary (underarm), areolar (around nipples), and anogenital areas, where they are always connected to a hair follicle.

 

 

  • These glands are responsible for producing a thick, viscous secretion that, once on the skin's surface, can be acted upon by bacteria, leading to the characteristic body odor associated with sweating.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Face

 

  • The face primarily contains eccrine sweat glands rather than apocrine glands.
  • Eccrine glands are involved in thermoregulation and are not typically associated with body odor.

 

Option C. Palms & soles

 

  • Like the face, the palms and soles predominantly feature eccrine sweat glands.
  • These areas are rich in these glands due to their role in grip and thermoregulation, not in scent secretion as is the function of apocrine glands.

 

Option D. Scalp

 

  • The scalp does contain apocrine glands, but they are not as prevalent as those found in the axillary region.
  • The scalp is also rich in sebaceous and eccrine glands, which contribute to the hair's health and moisture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The apocrine glands are present in the axilla, areolar (around nipples), and anogenital areas and their activity is associated with hair follicles in specific body regions, being primarily stimulated by hormonal changes, not by direct thermoregulatory needs.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 1 Page No 2.9

choices.text: Fordyce Spots
Tyson's Glands of the Prepuce
Meibomian Glands of the Eyelids
Kopliks Spots

questions.text: All of the following are examples of Ectopic Sebaceous Glands EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Koplik's Spots

 

Option D.

 

  • Koplik's spots are not ectopic sebaceous glands; they are a sign of measles, appearing as small, white lesions on the buccal mucosa.

 

 

  • Ectopic sebaceous glands:
    • Sebaceous glands are associated with and open into hair follicles.
    • But when they are located in areas of the body where they are not commonly found and are not associated with hair follicles i.e open directly onto the skin surface, we call them as Ectopic sebaceous glands.

 

 

 

Montgomery tubercles

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fordyce Spots:

 

  • They are true ectopic sebaceous glands found in the oral and genital mucosa.

 

 

Option B. Tyson's Glands

 

  • They are considered a form of ectopic sebaceous glands associated with the prepuce.

 

 

Option C. Meibomian Glands

  • They are modified sebaceous glands located in the eyelids and are responsible for secreting a lipid layer of the tear film.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Koplik's spots are not ectopic sebaceous glands; they are an oral manifestation of measles, whereas Fordyce spots, Tyson's glands, and Meibomian glands are all forms of ectopic or modified sebaceous glands.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition, Page No 2.9, 25.85

choices.text: Eccrine Sweat Glands
Apocrine Sweat Glands
Sebaceous Glands
Mammary Glands

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with Extremely Itchy Rashes in Both Armpits for the last 70 Days, as shown below. Histopathological Examination shows Dilation of the Follicular Infundibulum and Inflammatory Lymphohistiocytic Infiltration around the Infundibulum. Which Type of Glands are likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Apocrine Sweat Glands

 

Option B.

 

Fox-Fordyce Disease: (Apocrine Miliaria)

 

  • The description of the symptoms and histopathological findings is characteristic of Fox-Fordyce disease, which is a chronic pruritic inflammatory disorder of apocrine glands.
  • It is a disorder of the apocrine glands similar to the prickly heat of the eccrine glands
  • The possible aetiology is the obliteration of the apocrine duct at the infundibulum
  • It is common in post pubertal women but can also be seen in post-menopausal women
  • It typically presents with itchy skin-coloured papules in apocrine gland-rich areas such as the armpits, areola, and groin.

 

 

  • Early histological changes include keratin plugs within the follicular infundibulum, leading to blockage of the apocrine ducts, sweat retention, and eventual ductal rupture at the epidermal level, accompanied by lymphocytic inflammatory infiltration around the follicle and adjacent structures.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Eccrine Sweat Glands

 

  • They are not associated with hair follicles and do not typically present with the described histopathological changes.

 

Option C. Sebaceous Glands

 

  • They are usually associated with the pilosebaceous unit and do not cause the described dilation of the follicular infundibulum with the lymphohistiocytic infiltration.

 

Option D. Mammary Glands

 

  • They are not located in the armpits and do not present with such histopathological changes

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fox-Fordyce disease is associated with the apocrine sweat glands and is characterized by itchy, inflamed papules in areas where these glands are concentrated, such as the armpits, with histopathological findings of dilation and inflammation around the follicular infundibulum.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition, Page No 44.21

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 755

choices.text: Acne Conglobata
Acne Mechanica
Acne Fulminans
Acne Excoriee

questions.text: A 34-year-old female suffering from Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) presents with persistent Acne Scars. What can be the probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acne Excoriee

 

Option D.

 

  • The probable diagnosis for a 34-year-old female with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder presenting with persistent acne scars is Acne excoriee.
  • This condition is characterized by the patient picking at minor acne lesions or normal skin, leading to scarring.

 

 

  • It is commonly associated with stress and psychiatric conditions such as OCD

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acne Conglobata

 

  • It is a severe form of acne characterized by deep, inflamed nodules and abscesses, and not typically associated with OCD.

 

Option B. Acne Mechanica

 

  • It is incorrect as this is triggered by mechanical factors such as pressure, friction, rubbing, squeezing, or stretching.

 

Option C. Acne Fulminans

 

  • It is a sudden onset, severely inflammatory acne accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever and arthralgia, not primarily associated with OCD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acne excoriee is a form of acne that is exacerbated by the compulsive picking of the skin, often associated with psychiatric disorders such as OCD, and distinguished by Persistent Acne Scars.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition, Page No 90.23, 90.52

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 693

questions.text: Match the following conditions in Column A and the Column B
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-f, 2-e, 3-c, 4-b, 5-d, 6-a

 

 

 

  • Miliaria crystallina occurs when sweat is trapped under the stratum corneum, the outermost layer of the skin, due to obstruction of the eccrine sweat ducts.

 

 

  • Fordyce spots are ectopic sebaceous glands that appear on the body in places not typically associated with hair follicles.
  • Acne vulgaris is characterized by the obstruction of the pilosebaceous duct due to the buildup of sebum and keratin.
  • Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic skin condition involving the inflammation of apocrine sweat glands, leading to nodules, abscesses, and scarring.
  • Miliaria profunda is a deeper form of heat rash affecting the sweat glands at the dermoepidermal junction.
  • Miliaria rubra, also known as prickly heat, is caused by the obstruction of the eccrine sweat ducts within the epidermal layer called the stratum spinosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct matching of skin conditions to their pathophysiological description aids in understanding their underlying mechanisms, which is essential for accurate diagnosis and treatment in dermatology.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.24 111.5

Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 92 Page No 92.1-10

Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 94 Page No 94.12

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology, 9th Edition. Pg No:58

Online Resource https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534867/

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative agent for Acne Fulminans?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propionibacterium

 

Option B.

 

Cutibacterium Acnes (previously known as Propionibacterium Acnes)

 

  • It is the causative agent for Acne Fulminans/Acne Malinga.
  • Acne Fulminans is a Severe Destructive Form of Acne. It is predominantly seen in White, Adolescent Males.
  • The Exact Etiopathogenesis of this disease is unknown. Propionibacterium aces infection and the presence of elevated testosterone levels have been linked, though.

 

Clinically Presentation:

 

  • Numerous Hemorrhagic and Ulcerative Nodules suddenly appear on the Face, Back, and Trunk. Additionally, various indicators of systemic inflammation, such as Fever and Arthralgia, may coexist with the lesions.

 

Below image depicts erosive crusting lesions on the back of a young male with acne fulminans.

 

 

  • Mild to moderate acne that has been present for six months to two years, along with antimicrobial treatment failure is frequently an important clue in the history given by the patients of acne fulminans.

 

Features of Acne Fulminans:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bifidobacterium

 

  • It is a genus of gram-positive bacteria that is part of the normal flora of the human gut and does not cause acne.

 

Option C. Mobiluncus

 

  • This is a genus of bacteria that can be associated with bacterial vaginosis but is not a cause of acne.

 

Option D. Actinomyces

 

  • This is a genus of bacteria that can cause actinomycosis, which typically presents as chronic progressive suppurative disease, not acne.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cutibacterium acnes (formerly Propionibacterium acnes) is the bacteria associated with the pathogenesis of acne, including severe forms such as acne fulminans.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 90.50, 154.10

choices.text: Look for Dietary Triggers
Evaluate for Hyperandrogenism
Check for Antibiotic Resistance
Look for Drug Triggers

questions.text: A Female presented in Dermatology OPD with Acne that is not resolving on Oral Isotretinoin and Antibiotics Therapy. Which of the following is the next best step among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans.B) Evaluate for Hyperandrogenism

 

Option B.

 

  • Since the patient is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy, syndromes associated with acne should be evaluated and ruled out to reach a diagnosis. One of the important syndrome is HAIR-AN syndrome.
  • Hence, the next best step would be to evaluate for hyperandrogenism.

 

Important Syndromes Associated with Acne:

 

 

Different Therapies & their Mechanism of Action.

 

 

Explanation:

S

Option A: Looking for Dietary Triggers

 

  • It could be considered, but this should already be taken care of before prescribing isotretinoin and antibiotics.

 

Option C: Checking for Antibiotic Resistance:

 

  • This seems an appropriate step but can’t prioritize over ruling out HAIR-AN syndrome in this patient.

 

Option D: Drug Triggers

 

  • Drug triggers are unlikely to be the primary cause of acne patient who is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics.

 

Moreover, lesions in Drug-induced acne are monomorphic and comedones are absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When faced with a female patient whose acne has not improved with oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, the next best step is to evaluate for hyperandrogenism, which can point to an underlying hormonal cause such as PCOS, necessitating a different treatment approach.

 

Ref: Williams Gynaecology 4th Edition: Page No 392-394

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8826298/
